title: How to Cook Brussels Sprouts on the Stove, in the Oven & More

steps.title: Bring 1.5 cups (0.35 L) of water to a boil and add 1 tsp (5 g) of salt.
steps.content: Bring 1.5 cups (0.35 L) of water to a boil and add 1 tsp (5 g) of salt. Choose a pot or a saucepan that’s deep enough to accommodate all of your Brussels sprouts and cover them in water. The exact amount of water can vary as long as your halved sprouts are submerged.

steps.title: Wash the Brussels sprouts
steps.content: Wash the Brussels sprouts and slice them in half. While your water is heating up, rinse the sprouts under cold water, then peel off any yellow or brown leaves. Chop off the tough end at the bottom of each sprout, then slice them all in half to speed up the cooking time. [1] X Research source Sprouts can be boiled whole, but it will take longer to cook them all the way through (10-15 minutes instead of 4-5 minutes).

steps.title: Dump your sprouts into the boiling water and cook for 4-5 minutes.
steps.content: Dump your sprouts into the boiling water and cook for 4-5 minutes. Boil the Brussels sprouts until they’re crisp-tender (tender but still a little crunchy) and bright green. Spear a sprout with a fork and taste it to make sure it’s cooked all the way through. [2] X Research source Try not to overcook the Brussels sprouts. If they boil for too long, they’ll start to release a sulfuric compound which can make them taste bitter.

steps.title: Drain the sprouts and season with salt, pepper, butter, and Parmesan.
steps.content: Drain the sprouts and season with salt, pepper, butter, and Parmesan. Drain the cooked sprouts as soon as they’re tender to avoid overcooking them. Then, transfer them to a large bowl and sprinkle them with salt and pepper (to taste). Melt 2 tbsp (30 mL) of butter and toss. For extra flavor, top the sprouts with some grated Parmesan cheese and serve! [3] X Research source

steps.title: Wash and cut the Brussels sprouts in half lengthwise.
steps.content: Wash and cut the Brussels sprouts in half lengthwise. Run your sprouts under cold water, then remove any yellow or brown leaves. Trim off the tough ends, then slice each sprout in half longways. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Heat 2 US tbsp (30 mL) of olive oil in a skillet over medium-high heat.
steps.content: Heat 2 US tbsp (30 mL) of olive oil in a skillet over medium-high heat. Heat the oil until it’s runny and shimmering in the pan. Make sure your pan is wide enough to fit all of your sprouts in a single layer. [5] X Research source If you have more sprouts than your pan can fit, sautée them in 2 batches.

steps.title: Lay the sprouts cut-side down in the pan and season.
steps.content: Lay the sprouts cut-side down in the pan and season. Sprinkle 1 tsp (5.7 g) of salt (or to taste) and ¼ tsp (1.4 g) (or to taste) of black pepper evenly over the sprouts. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Sauté
steps.content: Sauté the sprouts until the bottoms are golden brown, then toss. Let the sprouts sit undisturbed in the pan for about 2 minutes until the bottoms look crispy and browned. Then, give them all a good toss with a wooden spoon or another utensil to flip them over. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Sauté the sprouts for another 4-5 minutes, tossing occasionally.
steps.content: Sauté the sprouts for another 4-5 minutes, tossing occasionally. Continue cooking the sprouts until they’re crisp-tender and a deep golden brown. Flip and toss them a few times so they cook evenly and don’t stick to your pan. [8] X Research source For minimal seasoning, remove the sprouts from the heat at this point. Toss with salt and pepper to taste and serve!

steps.title: Add 2 tbsp (28 g) of butter and 2 tsp (5.6 g) of minced garlic to the pan.
steps.content: Add 2 tbsp (28 g) of butter and 2 tsp (5.6 g) of minced garlic to the pan. Stir until the butter is fully melted and the garlic is fragrant. The extra fat and flavor will make your Brussels sprouts extra crispy and appetizing. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Stir in ¼ cup (20.8 g) of grated Parmesan cheese and serve.
steps.content: Stir in ¼ cup (20.8 g) of grated Parmesan cheese and serve. Toss in the cheese and stir for another 1-2 minutes until it’s melted and evenly covering the sprouts. Serve straight from the pan and enjoy! [10] X Research source For some next-level flavor, add a drizzle of balsamic glaze to your cheesy sprouts. Delicious!

steps.title: Preheat your oven to 400 °F (204 °C).
steps.content: Preheat your oven to 400 °F (204 °C). Preheating the oven first saves you time since you can rinse, chop, and prep your Brussels sprouts while the oven heats up. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Rinse, trim, and slice your Brussels sprouts in half.
steps.content: Rinse, trim , and slice your Brussels sprouts in half. Run the sprouts under cold water, then pluck off any yellow or brown leaves. Chop off the tough ends of each sprout, then slice them all in half lengthwise. Try to make each piece about the same size so they all cook evenly. [12] X Research source Halving the sprouts helps them cook all the way through without burning, and the extra surface area gives you more delicious, caramelized bits to enjoy. If you have frozen sprouts, skip the rinsing and slicing. Just season them and throw them on the baking sheet!

steps.title: Season the sprouts with olive oil, salt, and pepper in a large bowl or bag.
steps.content: Season the sprouts with olive oil, salt, and pepper in a large bowl or bag. Combine the sprouts with 3 US tbsp (44 mL) of olive oil, 1 tsp (5 g) of salt, and ½ tsp (2.5 g) of pepper and mix well so each piece is evenly coated. Mix with a large spoon or your hands in a big bowl, or dump the ingredients in a sealable bag and shake. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Place the sprouts in a single layer on a baking sheet.
steps.content: Place the sprouts in a single layer on a baking sheet. Don’t worry about placing them all cut-side down. You’ll be shaking the pan and tossing them several times while they bake, so they’ll get evenly cooked. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Roast the sprouts for 35-45 minutes until they’re brown and tender.
steps.content: Roast the sprouts for 35-45 minutes until they’re brown and tender. Shake the pan about every 5-7 minutes for even browning. [15] X Research source Smaller sprouts might be done closer to 30 or 35 minutes while larger ones may take around 45. [16] X Research source If you notice any burning, turn the heat down for the remainder of the roasting time. Test for tenderness by sticking a few sprouts with a fork. The prongs should glide right in.

steps.title: Serve your perfectly roasted sprouts right away.
steps.content: Serve your perfectly roasted sprouts right away. Eat them as they are or adjust the seasoning to your liking with extra salt or olive oil. To take things up a notch, squeeze some fresh lemon juice or drizzle a balsamic glaze over them, or sprinkle some panko bread crumbs and Parmesan cheese on top. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Rinse and slice your Brussels sprouts in half.
steps.content: Rinse and slice your Brussels sprouts in half. Run your sprouts under cool water, then pluck off any yellowing leaves. Trim the stems off and slice the sprouts in half lengthwise for even cooking. If you’ve got any extra large Brussels sprouts, slice them into quarters. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Add 2 US tbsp (30 mL) of oil or butter to a skillet on medium-high heat.
steps.content: Add 2 US tbsp (30 mL) of oil or butter to a skillet on medium-high heat. Heat olive oil until it’s shimmering in the pan, or butter until it’s completely melted. Choose a large skillet (at least 12 in (30 cm) across) that has a tightly fitting lid. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Place the sprouts cut-side down in the skillet and add salt and pepper.
steps.content: Place the sprouts cut-side down in the skillet and add salt and pepper. Once your fat of choice is nice and hot, arrange your sliced sprouts in a single layer in the pan. Then, sprinkle them evenly with salt and pepper to taste. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Sauté the sprouts until they begin to brown (about 5 minutes).
steps.content: Sauté the sprouts until they begin to brown (about 5 minutes). Let your Brussels sprouts sizzle and cook in your oil or butter, flipping or stirring occasionally to keep them from burning or sticking to the pan. You’re ready for the next step as soon as they start turning golden brown in a few spots. [21] X Research source

steps.title: Pour 1 cup (237 mL) of heavy cream into the pan and reduce the heat.
steps.content: Pour 1 cup (237 mL) of heavy cream into the pan and reduce the heat. Stir the cream with your fat, salt and pepper, and sprouts, then put a lid over the skillet to begin braising. Reduce the heat to a slow simmer. [22] X Research source For a lower-calorie vegan option, swap vegetable broth for heavy cream. The braising time will be much faster, too (5-10 minutes instead of 30). [23] X Research source

steps.title: Simmer
steps.content: Simmer the sprouts and heavy cream for 30-35 minutes. Check the sprouts for tenderness after 30 minutes. If they’re done, the tip of a sharp knife should slide into them easily. The heavy cream will have mostly evaporated and turned a light tan color. [24] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the lid, simmer until the cream thickens into a glaze, and serve.
steps.content: Remove the lid, simmer until the cream thickens into a glaze, and serve. Squirt a generous amount of fresh lemon juice into the pan and take a test bite. Adjust the flavor with more salt, pepper, or lemon juice as desired, then let the dish keep simmering for a few minutes with the lid off until the cream thickens into a rich glaze that coats the sprouts. [25] X Research source Once the glaze thickens, it’s time to dig in!

steps.title: Clean and trim your Brussels sprouts, then slice them in half.
steps.content: Clean and trim your Brussels sprouts, then slice them in half. Rinse off your sprouts in cool water, cut off the tough stems, then slice each sprout in half lengthwise (or into quarters if they’re extra large). Remove any brown or yellow leaves from the outside. [26] X Research source

steps.title: Place a basket steamer in a medium pot and fill with water.
steps.content: Place a basket steamer in a medium pot and fill with water. Add water until there’s about 1 in (2.5 cm) of space between the bottom of the basket and the top of the water. [27] X Research source If you don’t have a basket steamer, throw your sprouts right into the pot and fill with water until they’re about half covered. [28] X Research source

steps.title: Add your sprouts to the basket, cover the pot, and boil for 5 minutes.
steps.content: Add your sprouts to the basket, cover the pot, and boil for 5 minutes. The sprouts will begin steaming as soon as the water heats up. Keep the sprouts over the water for 5-8 minutes once it’s boiling (or until they’re fork tender). [29] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the steamed sprouts and toss in butter, salt, and pepper.
steps.content: Remove the steamed sprouts and toss in butter, salt, and pepper. Combine your hot sprouts, 2 US tbsp (30 mL) of butter, and salt and pepper (to taste) in a large bowl. Mix until the butter is melted and the sprouts are evenly coated. Then it’s time to dig in! [30] X Research source For extra flavor, sprinkle dried or fresh dill on top of your buttery Brussels sprouts. [31] X Research source

steps.title: Refrigerate leftover Brussels sprouts for up to 4 days.
steps.content: Refrigerate leftover Brussels sprouts for up to 4 days. After your meal, allow the extra sprouts to cool to room temperature (spread them out on a baking sheet to cool them faster). Then, transfer them to an airtight container and throw them in the fridge. They’ll last for up to 4 days (although it’ll be hard to resist them for that long!). [32] X Research source

steps.title: Reheat sprouts in the oven for 10 minutes at 350 °F (177 °C) for crispiness.
steps.content: Reheat sprouts in the oven for 10 minutes at 350 °F (177 °C) for crispiness. If you roasted or sautéed your sprouts and want to enjoy those crispy leaves for round 2, spread them out in a single layer on a baking sheet while you preheat the oven. Warm them for 10-12 minutes or until they’re hot all the way through, then enjoy! [33] X Research source

steps.title: Microwave sprouts in 30-second intervals until they’re heated through.
steps.content: Microwave sprouts in 30-second intervals until they’re heated through. For a fast reheat, throw your sprouts onto a microwave-safe plate or microwave crisper pan and heat them for 30 seconds. Give them a good stir so they warm up evenly, then continue heating in 15-30 second intervals until they’re piping hot and ready to eat. [34] X Research source It should take about 1 minute to reheat 1-2 servings of Brussels sprouts.
